children.subject: I have taken CS70, 61c, and 170. I have not taken 162. I found 170 to be the most manageable of the three. 70 has a lot of difficult hw, 170 has a manageable amount of conceptually difficult hw but if you get the concepts it isn't super crazy, and 61c has an ungodly, soul crushing workload of easy material that will make you feel like Sisyphus. 61c ate up so much of my time the semester I took it that I easily spent more time on it than all my other classes combined (and one of those classes was 170). Additionally I have heard rumors that 61c is switching the curriculum to be based off of ARM instead of MIPS which will mean that all the projects will be new or ported to a new platform and your TA's will also be as new to ARM as your are (unless they had other prior experience that most EECS/CS students don't get). I wouldn't advise taking 170 before 70 since 70 teaches you how to do proofs and you learn a lot of useful things in 70 that come into play in 170. I personally wouldn't take 61c and 70 together because of their workloads. I found 61c to be the most workload intensive class I have taken at Berkeley by a significant margin. I have heard pretty positive things about 162 but I can't speak to it personally. I would advise waiting on taking 61c because of the switch to ARM and being cautious about the workload of your other classes the semester you take it.

I actually already took 61c and 70 together last semester :) I am tentatively planning on taking 162+170, so i wanted to know how the workloads compare against each other, so I could see how much time I should expect to spend on work this semester.

I've taken 61c+70 together as well as 162+170 together. Overall, I would say 162+170 has a higher workload, but it should still be manageable. I ended up sacrificing a lot of time from 170 for 162 (in hindsight, I probably shouldn't have taken them together), but the workload of 162 is dependent on how good your group is. They have also reduced the amount of work required from when I took it (one less homework and less code you have to write in projects), so it shouldn't be too bad. As Anon posted above, 170's workload stems from its problem sets and is more conceptual than 70, so look at the problems when they're released and think of solutions in the back of your mind.
+1, also interested in knowing this. How much difference is there between CS70+61C and 162+170?

history.content: Probably manageable but maybe on the higher-workload side. 162 and 170 are both high-workload classes, but people frequently take them together. 161 is less work, but can spike in difficulty during projects.
Would this schedule be an overkill? If so, which should I drop between 162 and 161? The only other thing I plan on doing along with this is work-study about 10 hours a week. Thanks in advance :)
history.subject: CS161, CS162, CS170, and an L&S Breadth
